docfields.name: KPlotAxis
docfields.text: Contains all data for drawing an axis including format specification axis labels Andreas Nicolai 1.0

docfields.name: KPlotAxis::areTickLabelsShown
docfields.text: whether tick labels will be drawn for this axis

docfields.name: KPlotAxis::isVisible
docfields.text: whether the axis is visible or not

docfields.name: KPlotAxis::label
docfields.text: the label string for this axis

docfields.name: KPlotAxis::majorTickMarks
docfields.text: the list of coordinates of the major tickmarks for this axis the positions of tickmarks are automatically computed by setTickMarks() setTickMarks() minorTickMarks()

docfields.name: KPlotAxis::minorTickMarks
docfields.text: the list with the minor tickmarks the positions of tickmarks are automatically computed by setTickMarks() setTickMarks() majorTickMarks()

docfields.name: KPlotAxis::setLabel
docfields.text: Set the label to an empty string to omit the axis label label a string describing the data plotted on the axis

docfields.name: KPlotAxis::setTickLabelFormat
docfields.text: Normally the format character is one of e E f g or G see the documentation for QString::arg(double) for details In addition it is possible to set the format character to t in this case the tickmark value is interpreted as a time in hours and the ticklabel string will be in clock format Note that when the format character is t the fieldWidth and prec values are ignored format the format specification character fieldWidth the number of characters in the output string If set to 0 the string will be as wide as it needs to be to fully render the value precision the number of characters following the decimal point

docfields.name: KPlotAxis::setTickLabelsShown
docfields.text: b if true tick labels will be drawn

docfields.name: KPlotAxis::setTickMarks
docfields.text: this function is called by KPlotWidget whenever the plot s limits are modified x0 the minimum data coordinate of the axis length the range covered by the axis in data units majorTickMarks() minorTickMarks()

docfields.name: KPlotAxis::setVisible
docfields.text: visible if true this axis will be drawn on the KPlotWidget

docfields.name: KPlotAxis::tickLabel
docfields.text: the ticklabel string for the given value rendered according to the current format specification the value to be rendered as a tick label setTickLabelFormat()

docfields.name: KPlotAxis::tickLabelFormat
docfields.text: the number format of the tick labels

docfields.name: KPlotAxis::tickLabelPrecision
docfields.text: the number precision of the tick labels

docfields.name: KPlotAxis::tickLabelWidth
docfields.text: the field width of the tick labels

docfields.name: KPlotObject
docfields.text: Think of a KPlotObject as a set of data displayed as a group in the plot Each KPlotObject consists of a list of KPlotPoints a controlling how the data points are displayed some combination of Points Lines or Bars a color and a size There is also a parameter which controls the shape of the points used to display the KPlotObject KPlotObject will take care of the points added to it so when clearing the points list eg with clearPoints() any previous reference to a KPlotPoint already added to a KPlotObject will be invalid Jason Harris 1.1

docfields.name: KPlotObject::PlotType
docfields.text: These are bitmask values that can be OR d together so that a set of points can be represented in the plot in multiple ways points should be added in order of increasing x-coordinate when using Bars

docfields.name: KPlotObject::Points
docfields.text: each KPlotPoint is represented with a drawn point

docfields.name: KPlotObject::Lines
docfields.text: each KPlotPoint is connected with a line

docfields.name: KPlotObject::Bars
docfields.text: each KPlotPoint is shown as a vertical bar

docfields.name: KPlotObject::KPlotObject
docfields.text: color The color for plotting this object By default this sets the color for Points Lines and Bars but there are functions to override any of these otype the PlotType for this object Points Lines or Bars size the size to use for plotted points in pixels ps The PointStyle describing the shape for plotted points

docfields.name: KPlotObject::addPoint
docfields.text: p the QPointF to add label the optional text label for this point barWidth the width of the bar if this object is to be drawn with bars if barWidth is left at its default value of 0.0 then the width will be automatically set to the distance between this point and the one to its right

docfields.name: KPlotObject::addPoint
docfields.text: This is an overloaded member function provided for convenience It differs from the above function only in what argument(s) it accepts p pointer to the KPlotPoint to add

docfields.name: KPlotObject::addPoint
docfields.text: This is an overloaded member function provided for convenience It differs from the above function only in what argument(s) it accepts x the X-coordinate of the point to add y the Y-coordinate of the point to add label the optional text label barWidth the width of the bar if this object is to be drawn with bars if barWidth is left at its default value of 0.0 then the width will be automatically set to the distance between this point and the one to its right

docfields.name: KPlotObject::barBrush
docfields.text: the brush to use for filling bars for this Object

docfields.name: KPlotObject::barPen
docfields.text: the pen to use for drawing bars for this Object

docfields.name: KPlotObject::brush
docfields.text: the default Brush to use for this Object

docfields.name: KPlotObject::draw
docfields.text: p The QPainter to draw on pw the KPlotWidget to draw on this is needed for the KPlotWidget::mapToWidget() function

docfields.name: KPlotObject::labelPen
docfields.text: the pen to use for drawing labels for this Object

docfields.name: KPlotObject::linePen
docfields.text: the pen to use for drawing lines for this Object

docfields.name: KPlotObject::pen
docfields.text: the default pen for this Object If no other pens are set this pen will be used for points lines bars and labels this pen is always used for points

docfields.name: KPlotObject::plotTypes
docfields.text: the plot flags of the object

docfields.name: KPlotObject::points
docfields.text: the list of KPlotPoints that make up this object

docfields.name: KPlotObject::pointStyle
docfields.text: the style used for drawing the points in this object

docfields.name: KPlotObject::removePoint
docfields.text: index the index of the point to be removed

docfields.name: KPlotObject::setPointStyle
docfields.text: p the new style

docfields.name: KPlotObject::setShowBars
docfields.text: b if true bars will be drawn

docfields.name: KPlotObject::setShowLines
docfields.text: b if true lines will be drawn

docfields.name: KPlotObject::setShowPoints
docfields.text: b if true points will be drawn

docfields.name: KPlotObject::setSize
docfields.text: s the new size

docfields.name: KPlotObject::size
docfields.text: the size of the plotted points in this object in pixels

docfields.name: KPlotPoint
docfields.text: A KPlotPoint consists of X and Y coordinates in Data units an optional label string and an optional bar-width The bar-width is only used for plots of type KPlotObject::Bars and it allows the width of each bar to be set manually If bar-widths are omitted then the widths will be set automatically based on the halfway-mark between adjacent points

docfields.name: KPlotPoint::KPlotPoint
docfields.text: Sets the KPlotPoint according to the given arguments x the X-position for the point in Data units y the Y-position for the point in Data units label the label string for the point If the string is defined the point will be labeled in the plot width the bar width to use for this point only used for plots of type KPlotObject::Bars

docfields.name: KPlotPoint::KPlotPoint
docfields.text: Sets the KPlotPoint according to the given arguments p the position for the point in Data units label the label string for the point If the string is defined the point will be labeled in the plot width the bar width to use for this point only used for plots of type KPlotObject::Bars

docfields.name: KPlotPoint::barWidth
docfields.text: the bar-width for the point

docfields.name: KPlotPoint::label
docfields.text: the label for the point

docfields.name: KPlotPoint::position
docfields.text: the position of the point in data units

docfields.name: KPlotPoint::setPosition
docfields.text: pos the new position for the point

docfields.name: KPlotPoint::x
docfields.text: the X-position of the point in data units

docfields.name: KPlotPoint::y
docfields.text: the Y-position of the point in data units

docfields.name: KPlotWidget
docfields.text: Widget for drawing plots The basic idea behind KPlotWidget is that you don t have to worry about any transformation from your data s natural units to screen pixel coordinates this is handled internally by the widget Data to be plotted are represented by one or more instances of KPlotObject KPlotObject contains a list of QPointFs to be plotted again in the data s natural units as well as information about how the data are to be rendered in the plot i.e as separate points or connected by lines With what color and point style etc See KPlotObject for more information KPlotWidget automatically adds axis labels with tickmarks and tick labels These are encapsulated in the KPlotAxis class All you have to do is set the limits of the plotting area in data units and KPlotWidget wil figure out the optimal positions and labels for the tickmarks on the axes Example of usage KPlotWidget will take ownership of the objects added to it so when clearing the objects list eg with removeAllPlotObjects() any previous reference to a KPlotObject already added to a KPlotWidget will be invalid You can disable this behavior by using setAutoDelete(false) Jason Harris

docfields.name: KPlotWidget::LeftAxis
docfields.text: the left axis

docfields.name: KPlotWidget::BottomAxis
docfields.text: the bottom axis

docfields.name: KPlotWidget::RightAxis
docfields.text: the right axis

docfields.name: KPlotWidget::TopAxis
docfields.text: the top axis

docfields.name: KPlotWidget::setObjectToolTipShown
docfields.text: show whether show the tooltip isObjectToolTipShown()

docfields.name: KPlotWidget::setShowGrid
docfields.text: show if true grid lines will be drawn isGridShown()

docfields.name: KPlotWidget::KPlotWidget
docfields.text: parent the parent widget

docfields.name: KPlotWidget::addPlotObject
docfields.text: The widget takes ownership of the plot object unless auto-delete was disabled object the KPlotObject to be added

docfields.name: KPlotWidget::addPlotObjects
docfields.text: The widget takes ownership of the plot object unless auto-delete was disabled objects the list of KPlotObjects to be added

docfields.name: KPlotWidget::antialiasing
docfields.text: whether the antialiasing is active Antialiasing is not active by default

docfields.name: KPlotWidget::axis
docfields.text: the axis of the specified type or 0 if no axis has been set Axis

docfields.name: KPlotWidget::axis
docfields.text: the axis of the specified type or 0 if no axis has been set Axis

docfields.name: KPlotWidget::backgroundColor
docfields.text: the background color of the plot The default color is black

docfields.name: KPlotWidget::bottomPadding
docfields.text: the number of pixels below the plot area Padding values are set to by default if unchanged this function will try to guess a good value based on whether ticklabels and/or axis labels are to be drawn

docfields.name: KPlotWidget::dataRect
docfields.text: the rectangle representing the boundaries of the current plot in natural data units setLimits()

docfields.name: KPlotWidget::foregroundColor
docfields.text: the foreground color used for axes tickmarks and associated labels The default color is white

docfields.name: KPlotWidget::gridColor
docfields.text: the grid color The default color is gray

docfields.name: KPlotWidget::isGridShown
docfields.text: whether the grid lines are shown Grid lines are not shown by default

docfields.name: KPlotWidget::isObjectToolTipShown
docfields.text: whether the tooltip for the point objects is shown Tooltips are enabled by default

docfields.name: KPlotWidget::leftPadding
docfields.text: the number of pixels to the left of the plot area Padding values are set to by default if unchanged this function will try to guess a good value based on whether ticklabels and/or axis labels need to be drawn

docfields.name: KPlotWidget::mapToWidget
docfields.text: p from the data rect to the physical pixel rect Used mainly when drawing p the point to be converted in natural data units the coordinate in the pixel coordinate system

docfields.name: KPlotWidget::maskAlongLine
docfields.text: You should not normally call this function directly It is called by KPlotObject when lines are drawn in the plot p1 the starting point for the line p2 the ending point for the line value Allows you to determine how strongly the line should be avoided Larger values are avoided more strongly

docfields.name: KPlotWidget::maskRect
docfields.text: The rectangle is in pixel coordinates You should not normally call this function directly It is called by KPlotObject when points bars and labels are drawn r the rectangle defining the region in the plot that text labels should avoid in pixel coordinates value Allows you to determine how strongly the rectangle should be avoided Larger values are avoided more strongly

docfields.name: KPlotWidget::minimumSizeHint
docfields.text: suggested minimum size for the plot widget

docfields.name: KPlotWidget::pixRect
docfields.text: the rectangle representing the boundaries of the current plot in screen pixel units

docfields.name: KPlotWidget::placeLabel
docfields.text: This function will attempt to place the label as close as it can to the point to which the label belongs while avoiding overlap with regions of the plot that have been masked You should not normally call this function directly It is called internally in KPlotObject::draw() painter Pointer to the painter on which to draw the label pp pointer to the KPlotPoint whose label is to be drawn

docfields.name: KPlotWidget::plotObjects
docfields.text: the current list of plot objects

docfields.name: KPlotWidget::removeAllPlotObjects
docfields.text: If auto-delete was not disabled the plot objects are deleted

docfields.name: KPlotWidget::replacePlotObject
docfields.text: i the index of the item to be replaced o pointer to the replacement KPlotObject 5.12 if auto-deletion is enabled the previous plot object is deleted Call setAutoDeletePlotObjects(false) if you want to swap between available plot objects and therefore you want to handle deletion externally

docfields.name: KPlotWidget::rightPadding
docfields.text: the number of pixels to the right of the plot area Padding values are set to by default if unchanged this function will try to guess a good value based on whether ticklabels and/or axis labels are to be drawn

docfields.name: KPlotWidget::secondaryDataRect
docfields.text: the rectangle representing the boundaries of the secondary data limits if they have been set Otherwise this function behaves the same as dataRect() setSecondaryLimits()

docfields.name: KPlotWidget::setAntialiasing
docfields.text: b if true the plot graphics will be antialiased

docfields.name: KPlotWidget::setAutoDeletePlotObjects
docfields.text: Auto-deletion is enabled by default 5.12

docfields.name: KPlotWidget::setBackgroundColor
docfields.text: bg the new background color

docfields.name: KPlotWidget::setBottomPadding
docfields.text: Set this to to revert to automatic determination of padding values

docfields.name: KPlotWidget::setForegroundColor
docfields.text: fg the new foreground color

docfields.name: KPlotWidget::setGridColor
docfields.text: gc the new grid color

docfields.name: KPlotWidget::setLeftPadding
docfields.text: Set this to to revert to automatic determination of padding values

docfields.name: KPlotWidget::setLimits
docfields.text: x1 the minimum X value in data units x2 the maximum X value in data units y1 the minimum Y value in data units y2 the maximum Y value in data units

docfields.name: KPlotWidget::setRightPadding
docfields.text: Set this to to revert to automatic determination of padding values

docfields.name: KPlotWidget::setSecondaryLimits
docfields.text: All data points are plotted using the coordinates defined by setLimits() so this function is only useful for showing alternate tickmark labels along the top and right edges For example if you were plotting temperature on the X-axis you could use Centigrade units for the primary bottom axis using setLimits 0.0 100.0 0.0 1.0 If you also wanted to show Farenheit units along the secondary top axis you would additionally use setSecondaryLimits 32.0 212.0 0.0 1.0 The data added to the plot would have x-coordinates in Centigrade degrees x1 the minimum X value in secondary data units x2 the maximum X value in secondary data units y1 the minimum Y value in secondary data units y2 the maximum Y value in secondary data units setLimits()

docfields.name: KPlotWidget::setTopPadding
docfields.text: Set this to to revert to automatic determination of padding values

docfields.name: KPlotWidget::sizeHint
docfields.text: suggested size for the plot widget

docfields.name: KPlotWidget::topPadding
docfields.text: the number of pixels above the plot area Padding values are set to by default if unchanged this function will try to guess a good value based on whether ticklabels and/or axis labels are to be drawn

docfields.name: KPlotWidget::drawAxes
docfields.text: Internal use only one should simply call update() to draw the widget with axes and all objects p pointer to the painter on which we are drawing

docfields.name: KPlotWidget::pointsUnderPoint
docfields.text: a list of points in the plot which are within 4 pixels of the screen position given as an argument p The screen position from which to check for plot points

docfields.name: index
docfields.text: KPlotting Data plotting Introduction KPlotWidget is a QWidget-derived class that provides a virtual base class for easy data-plotting The idea behind KPlotWidget is that you only have to specify information in i.e the natural units of the data being plotted KPlotWidget automatically converts everything to screen pixel units KPlotWidget draws X and Y axes with tick marks and tick labels It automatically determines how many tick marks to use and where they should be based on the data limits specified for the plot You change the limits by calling setLimits(double x1, double x2, double y1, double y2) Data to be plotted are stored using the KPlotObject class KPlotObject consists of a QList of QPointF s each specifying the X Y coordinates of a data point KPlotObject also specifies the of data to be plotted POINTS or CURVE or POLYGON or LABEL
